elements.content: Upon the basis of a bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2L), a new (3,6)-connected metal–organic framework with pyr topology, [Cu­(L)·DMF] n (NJU-Bai32), has been synthesized and exhibits highly selective CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Upon the basis of a bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)isophthalic acid (H2L), a new (3,6)-connected metal-organic framework with pyr topology, [Cu(L)⋅DMF] n  (NJU-Bai32), has been synthesized and exhibits highly selective CO2 adsorption.

elements.content:
A (3,6)-connected metal−organic framework with pyr topology and highly selective CO2 adsorption has been synthesized.

Global warming induced by the excessive emission of CO2 has been one of great concerns facing our civilization today. As a major CO2 release source, flue gas from power plants composed mainly of 73–77% of N2, 15–16% of CO2, 5−7% of H2O and others and at a total pressure of ∼1 bar has prompted the rapid development of postcombustion CO2 capture with different kinds of materials. Conventional technologies for postcombustion CO2 capture involving the chemisorption by amine-solution systems encounter high cost and corrosion in their regeneration process. Therefore, recently, these alternative processes in relation to physisorption by solid porous adsorbents have been intensively developed. Compared to traditional porous materials (zeolite, active carbon, and others), metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with more fascinating structures and properties of large porosity, functionalizable pore surface, and tunable pore sizes and shapes have been considered to be the most promising materials for CO2 capture.
elements.clean_text:
A (3,6)-connected metal-organic framework with pyr topology and highly selective CO2 adsorption has been synthesized.

Global warming induced by the excessive emission of CO2 has been one of great concerns facing our civilization today. As a major CO2 release source, flue gas from power plants composed mainly of 73-77% of N2, 15-16% of CO2, 5-7% of H2O and others and at a total pressure of ~1 bar has prompted the rapid development of postcombustion CO2 capture with different kinds of materials. Conventional technologies for postcombustion CO2 capture involving the chemisorption by amine-solution systems encounter high cost and corrosion in their regeneration process. Therefore, recently, these alternative processes in relation to physisorption by solid porous adsorbents have been intensively developed. Compared to traditional porous materials (zeolite, active carbon, and others), metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with more fascinating structures and properties of large porosity, functionalizable pore surface, and tunable pore sizes and shapes have been considered to be the most promising materials for CO2 capture.

elements.content: Our work is focused upon the construction of MOFs possessing interesting properties from both symmetric and unsymmetric multidentate organic ligands. For example, very recently, two (3,6)-connected MOFs with rtl topology, NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8, were reported which were constructed from 5-(pyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid and 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)­isophthalic acid, respectively. Targeting the (3,6)-connected framework, SYSU, they were designed by shifting the coordination site of ligand to finely tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated nitrogen atoms, respectively, and both of them exhibited highly selective adsorption for CO2. Herein, to further expand our work, a new bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2L), with the pyrimidin-5-yl group substituting the pyridin-3-yl or pyrimidin-5-yl group in 5-(pyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid or 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)­isophthalic acid was designed and used to synthesize a new (3,6)-connected MOF with pyr topology, NJU-Bai32, which is the second reported pyr topological MOF constructed from a bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor and exhibits highly selective CO2 adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Our work is focused upon the construction of MOFs possessing interesting properties from both symmetric and unsymmetric multidentate organic ligands. For example, very recently, two (3,6)-connected MOFs with rtl topology, NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8, were reported which were constructed from 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid and 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid, respectively. Targeting the (3,6)-connected framework, SYSU, they were designed by shifting the coordination site of ligand to finely tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated nitrogen atoms, respectively, and both of them exhibited highly selective adsorption for CO2. Herein, to further expand our work, a new bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)isophthalic acid (H2L), with the pyrimidin-5-yl group substituting the pyridin-3-yl or pyrimidin-5-yl group in 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid or 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid was designed and used to synthesize a new (3,6)-connected MOF with pyr topology, NJU-Bai32, which is the second reported pyr topological MOF constructed from a bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor and exhibits highly selective CO2 adsorption.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of CuCl2·2H2O with H2L in N,N-dimethylacetamide/methanol containing HNO3 afforded green block crystals of NJU-Bai32. Single X-ray crystal structure revealed that it crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbca with a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, and c = 21.6987(15) Å. Similar to NJU-Bai7, in the structure of NJU-Bai32, Cu-paddlewheel units are linked by isophthalic acid moieties of the organic ligand leading to the formation of two-dimensional (2D) square topological layers (sql). Then, the 2D sql nets of Cu-paddelwheel units joined by isophthalic acid moieties are further pillared by the quinolin-4-yl group giving the formation of three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks (). However, different from the structure of NJU-Bai7, along the opposite direction of the c axis, these sql layers in NJU-Bai32 adopt the packing model of the AB stacking model, in which layer of B is turned from layer of A by a translation of 1/2 a opposite the direction of a axis after a rotation of 180° along c axis. Interestingly, one-dimensional zigzag channels are generated to be perpendicular to the 2D sql layers in NJU-Bai32. The pore size (determined by the van der Waals diameter of the inserted pseudoatom) around the quinolin-4-yl group which may be rotated around the Cu–N bond and the linker backbone as gas molecules adsorbed diffuse into the pores is 2.8 Å and that around the sql layer is 4.5 Å (e). To better describe the structure, NJU-Bai32 may be simplified as a (3,6)-connected network with pyr topology, calculated by TOPOS software, in which the Cu-paddlewheel units serve as 6-connected nodes and the organic ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes. As far as we know, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligands with two carboxyl groups and one N donor after the previous publication of unstable MCF-30 by Chen’s group.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reaction of CuCl2⋅2H2O with H2L in N,N-dimethylacetamide/methanol containing HNO3 afforded green block crystals of NJU-Bai32. Single X-ray crystal structure revealed that it crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbca with a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, and c = 21.6987(15) Å. Similar to NJU-Bai7, in the structure of NJU-Bai32, Cu-paddlewheel units are linked by isophthalic acid moieties of the organic ligand leading to the formation of two-dimensional (2D) square topological layers (sql). Then, the 2D sql nets of Cu-paddelwheel units joined by isophthalic acid moieties are further pillared by the quinolin-4-yl group giving the formation of three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks (). However, different from the structure of NJU-Bai7, along the opposite direction of the c axis, these sql layers in NJU-Bai32 adopt the packing model of the AB stacking model, in which layer of B is turned from layer of A by a translation of 1/2 a  opposite the direction of a axis after a rotation of 180° along c axis. Interestingly, one-dimensional zigzag channels are generated to be perpendicular to the 2D sql layers in NJU-Bai32. The pore size (determined by the van der Waals diameter of the inserted pseudoatom) around the quinolin-4-yl group which may be rotated around the Cu-N bond and the linker backbone as gas molecules adsorbed diffuse into the pores is 2.8 Å and that around the sql layer is 4.5 Å (e). To better describe the structure, NJU-Bai32 may be simplified as a (3,6)-connected network with pyr topology, calculated by TOPOS software, in which the Cu-paddlewheel units serve as 6-connected nodes and the organic ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes. As far as we know, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligands with two carboxyl groups and one N donor after the previous publication of unstable MCF-30 by Chen's group.

elements.content: (a, b) Cu-paddlewheel units linked by isophthalic acid moieties form the two-dimensional (2D) sql layers (marked A and B in b) which are pillared by a quinolin-4-yl group to construct the three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks. (c) Pillaring of quinolin-4-yl groups between layers of A and B. (d) The pyr topology of NJU-Bai32 which more clearly exhibits the transformation of layer of A to B. (e) One-dimensional (1D) zigzag channel perpendicular to the 2D sql layers generated in NJU-Bai32 with two kinds of pore sizes. H atom is omitted for clarity. C, gray; O, red; Cu, cyan; N, blue.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a, b) Cu-paddlewheel units linked by isophthalic acid moieties form the two-dimensional (2D) sql layers (marked A and B in b) which are pillared by a quinolin-4-yl group to construct the three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks. (c) Pillaring of quinolin-4-yl groups between layers of A and B. (d) The pyr topology of NJU-Bai32 which more clearly exhibits the transformation of layer of A to B. (e) One-dimensional (1D) zigzag channel perpendicular to the 2D sql layers generated in NJU-Bai32 with two kinds of pore sizes. H atom is omitted for clarity. C, gray; O, red; Cu, cyan; N, blue.

elements.content: The total potential solvent accessible volume in desolvated NJU-Bai32 is around 35.5% as determined by the PLATON/SOLV program, and the calculated density is 1.261 g cm–3. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of NJU-Bai32 also imply that the whole porous framework still retains the crystallinity even if the guest molecules have been removed from the pores.
elements.clean_text: The total potential solvent accessible volume in desolvated NJU-Bai32 is around 35.5% as determined by the PLATON/SOLV program, and the calculated density is 1.261 g cm-3. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of NJU-Bai32 also imply that the whole porous framework still retains the crystallinity even if the guest molecules have been removed from the pores.

elements.content: To confirm the permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32, the acetone solvent-exchanged sample was degassed under a high vacuum by heating for 10 h to obtain the evacuated framework. As shown in Figure S3, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 195 K for NJU-Bai32, and the reversible type-I isotherm implies that this metal–organic framework is a microporous material. The estimated apparent BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of NJU-Bai32 are 751 and 842 m2 g–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: To confirm the permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32, the acetone solvent-exchanged sample was degassed under a high vacuum by heating for 10 h to obtain the evacuated framework. As shown in Figure S3, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 195 K for NJU-Bai32, and the reversible type-I isotherm implies that this metal-organic framework is a microporous material. The estimated apparent BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of NJU-Bai32 are 751 and 842 m2 g-1, respectively.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32 prompted us to investigate its selective adsorption properties of CO2 versus N2. The CO2 and N2 low-pressure (0–1 bar) sorption isotherms were collected for NJU-Bai32 at 273 and 298 K, as shown in Figures S4 and S6. Very interestingly, at 298 K, its uptake amount of CO2 is high up to 24 cm3 g–1, corresponding to ∼4.7 wt % at 0.15 bar, which is substantially higher than the values of many well-known MOFs, such as ZIF-78 (3.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), NH2-MIL-53­(Al) (3.2 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), en-Cu-BTTri (2.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), ZIF-8 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), and MOF-177 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar). However, it is worthy of note that in sharp contrast to CO2, NJU-Bai32 can only adsorb a limited amount of N2 (3.6 cm3 g–1, corresponding to ∼0.45 wt %) at 298 K and 0.75 bar.
elements.clean_text: The permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32 prompted us to investigate its selective adsorption properties of CO2 versus N2. The CO2 and N2 low-pressure (0-1 bar) sorption isotherms were collected for NJU-Bai32 at 273 and 298 K, as shown in Figures S4 and S6. Very interestingly, at 298 K, its uptake amount of CO2 is high up to 24 cm3 g-1, corresponding to ~4.7 wt % at 0.15 bar, which is substantially higher than the values of many well-known MOFs, such as ZIF-78 (3.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), NH2-MIL-53(Al) (3.2 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), en-Cu-BTTri (2.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), ZIF-8 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), and MOF-177 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar). However, it is worthy of note that in sharp contrast to CO2, NJU-Bai32 can only adsorb a limited amount of N2 (3.6 cm3 g-1, corresponding to ~0.45 wt %) at 298 K and 0.75 bar.

elements.content: To evaluate the selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 for NJU-Bai32, its selectivity for CO2 over N2 based on a CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85) mixture was calculated from the experimental single-component isotherms using the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) method (). At 298 K, NJU-Bai32 exhibits a good selectivity for CO2/N2, which is ∼70.5 at 1 bar. In addition, the separation ratio of CO2 versus N2 for NJU-Bai32 was also calculated from the ratio of the initial slopes based on the isotherms (Figure S8). At 298 K, it is ∼48.2, which is much higher than the value of SYSU at 298 K and even approaches that of NJU-Bai7 at 298 K (Table S3). It is worthy of note that the high CO2 adsorption uptake and selectivity for CO2/N2 may be derived from the narrow pores in NJU-Bai32.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 for NJU-Bai32, its selectivity for CO2 over N2 based on a CO2/N2 (0.15:0.85) mixture was calculated from the experimental single-component isotherms using the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) method (). At 298 K, NJU-Bai32 exhibits a good selectivity for CO2/N2, which is ~70.5 at 1 bar. In addition, the separation ratio of CO2 versus N2 for NJU-Bai32 was also calculated from the ratio of the initial slopes based on the isotherms (Figure S8). At 298 K, it is ~48.2, which is much higher than the value of SYSU at 298 K and even approaches that of NJU-Bai7 at 298 K (Table S3). It is worthy of note that the high CO2 adsorption uptake and selectivity for CO2/N2 may be derived from the narrow pores in NJU-Bai32.

elements.content: Low pressure gases adsorption isotherms and the dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich (DSLF) fit lines of CO2 and N2 in NJU-Bai32 at 298 K. The green line and symbol show the IAST predicted selectivity of CO2 over N2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Low pressure gases adsorption isotherms and the dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich (DSLF) fit lines of CO2 and N2 in NJU-Bai32 at 298 K. The green line and symbol show the IAST predicted selectivity of CO2 over N2.

elements.content: To further understand these observations, the isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 adsorption for NJU-Bai33 was calculated to evaluate the extent of CO2–framework interactions by the virial method using experimental isotherm data at 273 and 298 K (). At zero loading, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy for NJU-Bai32 is calculated to be 33.5 kJ mol–1, which reflects a strong interaction between the framework and adsorbed CO2 molecule. This Q st that is lower than the value of NJU-Bai7 is still higher than that of its prototype, SYSU, which is constructed by the same sql layers to NJU-Bai32 with its final pore size much larger than the kinetic diameters of adsorbate molecules. Consequently, we attribute the higher Q st value in NJU-Bai32 to the pore sizes close to the kinetic diameter of CO2 molecule in the framework, which could facilitate the adsorbent–adsorbate interaction.
elements.clean_text: To further understand these observations, the isosteric heat (Q st) of CO2 adsorption for NJU-Bai33 was calculated to evaluate the extent of CO2-framework interactions by the virial method using experimental isotherm data at 273 and 298 K (). At zero loading, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy for NJU-Bai32 is calculated to be 33.5 kJ mol-1, which reflects a strong interaction between the framework and adsorbed CO2 molecule. This Q st that is lower than the value of NJU-Bai7 is still higher than that of its prototype, SYSU, which is constructed by the same sql layers to NJU-Bai32 with its final pore size much larger than the kinetic diameters of adsorbate molecules. Consequently, we attribute the higher Q st value in NJU-Bai32 to the pore sizes close to the kinetic diameter of CO2 molecule in the framework, which could facilitate the adsorbent-adsorbate interaction.

elements.content: CO2 adsorption enthalpies of SYSU (green), NJU-Bai32 (pink), and NJU-Bai7 (purple).
elements.clean_text: 3  CO2 adsorption enthalpies of SYSU (green), NJU-Bai32 (pink), and NJU-Bai7 (purple).

elements.content: In summary, upon the basis of a quinoline-heterocyclic bifunctional organic ligand, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)­isophthalic acid (H2L), a new (3,6)-connected MOF with pyr topology, NJU-Bai32, has been successfully synthesized. Notably, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor. Very interestingly, with suitable and narrowed pore size, it also exhibits high selective CO2 adsorption uptake, which is better than those of many well-known MOFs reported previously.
elements.clean_text: In summary, upon the basis of a quinoline-heterocyclic bifunctional organic ligand, 5-(quinolin-4-yl)isophthalic acid (H2L), a new (3,6)-connected MOF with pyr topology, NJU-Bai32, has been successfully synthesized. Notably, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligand with two carboxyl groups and one N donor. Very interestingly, with suitable and narrowed pore size, it also exhibits high selective CO2 adsorption uptake, which is better than those of many well-known MOFs reported previously.

cln_elements.content:
Solvothermal reaction of CuCl2·2H2O with H2L in N,N-dimethylacetamide/methanol containing HNO3 afforded green block crystals of NJU-Bai32. Single X-ray crystal structure revealed that it crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbca with a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, and c = 21.6987(15) Å. Similar to NJU-Bai7, in the structure of NJU-Bai32, Cu-paddlewheel units are linked by isophthalic acid moieties of the organic ligand leading to the formation of two-dimensional (2D) square topological layers (sql). Then, the 2D sql nets of Cu-paddelwheel units joined by isophthalic acid moieties are further pillared by the quinolin-4-yl group giving the formation of three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks (). However, different from the structure of NJU-Bai7, along the opposite direction of the c axis, these sql layers in NJU-Bai32 adopt the packing model of the AB stacking model, in which layer of B is turned from layer of A by a translation of 1/2 a opposite the direction of a axis after a rotation of 180° along c axis. Interestingly, one-dimensional zigzag channels are generated to be perpendicular to the 2D sql layers in NJU-Bai32. The pore size (determined by the van der Waals diameter of the inserted pseudoatom) around the quinolin-4-yl group which may be rotated around the Cu–N bond and the linker backbone as gas molecules adsorbed diffuse into the pores is 2.8 Å and that around the sql layer is 4.5 Å (e). To better describe the structure, NJU-Bai32 may be simplified as a (3,6)-connected network with pyr topology, calculated by TOPOS software, in which the Cu-paddlewheel units serve as 6-connected nodes and the organic ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes. As far as we know, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligands with two carboxyl groups and one N donor after the previous publication of unstable MCF-30 by Chen’s group.

The total potential solvent accessible volume in desolvated NJU-Bai32 is around 35.5% as determined by the PLATON/SOLV program, and the calculated density is 1.261 g cm–3. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of NJU-Bai32 also imply that the whole porous framework still retains the crystallinity even if the guest molecules have been removed from the pores.

To confirm the permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32, the acetone solvent-exchanged sample was degassed under a high vacuum by heating for 10 h to obtain the evacuated framework. As shown in Figure S3, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 195 K for NJU-Bai32, and the reversible type-I isotherm implies that this metal–organic framework is a microporous material. The estimated apparent BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of NJU-Bai32 are 751 and 842 m2 g–1, respectively.

The permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32 prompted us to investigate its selective adsorption properties of CO2 versus N2. The CO2 and N2 low-pressure (0–1 bar) sorption isotherms were collected for NJU-Bai32 at 273 and 298 K, as shown in Figures S4 and S6. Very interestingly, at 298 K, its uptake amount of CO2 is high up to 24 cm3 g–1, corresponding to ∼4.7 wt % at 0.15 bar, which is substantially higher than the values of many well-known MOFs, such as ZIF-78 (3.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), NH2-MIL-53­(Al) (3.2 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), en-Cu-BTTri (2.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), ZIF-8 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), and MOF-177 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar). However, it is worthy of note that in sharp contrast to CO2, NJU-Bai32 can only adsorb a limited amount of N2 (3.6 cm3 g–1, corresponding to ∼0.45 wt %) at 298 K and 0.75 bar.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Crystal data for NJU-Bai32, [Cu(L)·DMF] n : C20H16CuN2O5, M r = 427.89, orthorhombic, Pbca, a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, c = 21.6987(15) Å, α = β = γ = 90, V = 3737.2(4) Å3, Z = 8, D c = 1.521 g cm–3, F 000 = 1752, T = 150(2) K, 32274 reflections collected, 4292 independent reflections (R int = 0.0516) R 1 = 0.0338, wR 2 = 0.0916 for [I > 2σ(I)] and GOF = 1.015.

Solvothermal reaction of CuCl2⋅2H2O with H2L in N,N-dimethylacetamide/methanol containing HNO3 afforded green block crystals of NJU-Bai32. Single X-ray crystal structure revealed that it crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbca with a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, and c = 21.6987(15) Å. Similar to NJU-Bai7, in the structure of NJU-Bai32, Cu-paddlewheel units are linked by isophthalic acid moieties of the organic ligand leading to the formation of two-dimensional (2D) square topological layers (sql). Then, the 2D sql nets of Cu-paddelwheel units joined by isophthalic acid moieties are further pillared by the quinolin-4-yl group giving the formation of three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks (). However, different from the structure of NJU-Bai7, along the opposite direction of the c axis, these sql layers in NJU-Bai32 adopt the packing model of the AB stacking model, in which layer of B is turned from layer of A by a translation of 1/2 a  opposite the direction of a axis after a rotation of 180° along c axis. Interestingly, one-dimensional zigzag channels are generated to be perpendicular to the 2D sql layers in NJU-Bai32. The pore size (determined by the van der Waals diameter of the inserted pseudoatom) around the quinolin-4-yl group which may be rotated around the Cu-N bond and the linker backbone as gas molecules adsorbed diffuse into the pores is 2.8 Å and that around the sql layer is 4.5 Å (e). To better describe the structure, NJU-Bai32 may be simplified as a (3,6)-connected network with pyr topology, calculated by TOPOS software, in which the Cu-paddlewheel units serve as 6-connected nodes and the organic ligands are simplified as 3-connected nodes. As far as we know, it is the second reported pyr topological MOF based upon bifunctional organic ligands with two carboxyl groups and one N donor after the previous publication of unstable MCF-30 by Chen's group. 

The total potential solvent accessible volume in desolvated NJU-Bai32 is around 35.5% as determined by the PLATON/SOLV program, and the calculated density is 1.261 g cm-3. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of NJU-Bai32 also imply that the whole porous framework still retains the crystallinity even if the guest molecules have been removed from the pores.

To confirm the permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32, the acetone solvent-exchanged sample was degassed under a high vacuum by heating for 10 h to obtain the evacuated framework. As shown in Figure S3, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 195 K for NJU-Bai32, and the reversible type-I isotherm implies that this metal-organic framework is a microporous material. The estimated apparent BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of NJU-Bai32 are 751 and 842 m2 g-1, respectively.

The permanent porosity of NJU-Bai32 prompted us to investigate its selective adsorption properties of CO2 versus N2. The CO2 and N2 low-pressure (0-1 bar) sorption isotherms were collected for NJU-Bai32 at 273 and 298 K, as shown in Figures S4 and S6. Very interestingly, at 298 K, its uptake amount of CO2 is high up to 24 cm3 g-1, corresponding to ~4.7 wt % at 0.15 bar, which is substantially higher than the values of many well-known MOFs, such as ZIF-78 (3.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), NH2-MIL-53(Al) (3.2 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), en-Cu-BTTri (2.4 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), ZIF-8 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar), and MOF-177 (0.6 wt %, at 298 K and 0.15 bar). However, it is worthy of note that in sharp contrast to CO2, NJU-Bai32 can only adsorb a limited amount of N2 (3.6 cm3 g-1, corresponding to ~0.45 wt %) at 298 K and 0.75 bar.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Crystal data for NJU-Bai32, [Cu(L)⋅DMF] n : C20H16CuN2O5, M  r  = 427.89, orthorhombic, Pbca, a = 14.3026(10) Å, b = 12.0421(8) Å, c = 21.6987(15) Å, α = β = γ = 90, V = 3737.2(4) Å3, Z = 8, D c = 1.521 g cm-3, F 000 = 1752, T = 150(2) K, 32274 reflections collected, 4292 independent reflections (R int = 0.0516) R 1 = 0.0338, wR 2 = 0.0916 for [I > 2σ(I)] and GOF = 1.015.

(c) Pillaring of quinolin-4-yl groups between layers of A and B. (d) The pyr topology of NJU-Bai32 which more clearly exhibits the transformation of layer of A to B. (e) One-dimensional (1D) zigzag channel perpendicular to the 2D sql layers generated in NJU-Bai32 with two kinds of pore sizes. H atom is omitted for clarity. C, gray; O, red; Cu, cyan; N, blue.

metadata.title:
A (3,6)-Connected
Metal–Organic Framework with pyr Topology
and Highly Selective CO2 Adsorption
